Text:
1st Airborne Reconnaissance Squadron - The Freddie Gough Squadron. 
This black Scottish granite memorial is dedicated to the men of the 1st Airborne Reconnaissance Squadron, known as the Freddie Gough Squadron. The 1st Airborne Reconnaissance Squadron was a Reconnaissance Corps unit which formed part of the 1st Airborne Division and was sent to North Africa, seeing service in Italy, Arnhem and finally in Norway. It had various names before the authorities settled on the name by which it was finally known.  The first commanding officer was Major Freddie Gough and it quickly became known as the Freddie Gough Squadron. It should be noted that Major Gough came from a distinguished military family (see below). Charles Frederick Howard “Freddie” Gough was born in India in September 1901. He was awarded the MC for his actions with the Squadron during the Italian Campaign. The Squadron took part in the Battle of Arnhem; hence the location of this memorial. Freddie Gough was taken prisoner at the Bridge at Arnhem and remained a POW until he escaped in April 1945. 75 men from the Squadron escaped from the Arnhem Battle and at the end of the war were sent to Norway to help disarm the German occupying forces. During the autumn of 1945 the Squadron was demobilised. After the war Freddie Gough was Member of Parliament for Horsham and died at the age of 76 while on holiday on Italy in 1977.

Three members of the Gough family were awarded the Victoria Cross.

216 SQUADRON ROYAL AIR FORCE
In 1918 ‘A’ Squadron, Royal Naval Air Service was renumbered as No 216 (two-sixteen) Squadron Royal Air Force. It was designated a bomber-transport squadron for strategic bombing during the latter stages of WW1 and during the inter war years in the Middle East. On the outbreak of war with Italy in June 1940 the units’ aircraft undertook bombing sorties, then concentrated on transport flying, moving squadrons around the Middle East and Greece and keeping open the supply and reinforcement routes. In 1941 the Squadron agreed to provide a Bristol Bombay aircraft for the newly formed SAS for its first real parachute jump into the North African Desert. . 1955, the Squadron returned to the United Kingdom and received the Comet 2 aircraft and continued to operate these aircraft in the transport role, particularly for Royal and VIP flights. During the Falklands War the Squadron assumed the task off a refuelling Unit including the twice weekly schedule to the Falklands Islands At the end of July 1990, Iraq invaded Kuwait. No 216 Squadron with eight Tri star aircraft made a significant contribution including air-to-air refuelling and troop-carrying in support of both the RAF and US Navy, as it did later in Iraq and Afghanistan In 2020 No. 216 Squadron reformed to become an experimental unit that will test future drone swarm technology. Based at RAF Waddington. The memorial was dedicated in April 2022.

3 (Fighter) Squadron RAF; 3 Squadron RAF 
The No. 3 Fighter Squadron Memorial honours the courage and sacrifice of those who have given their lives to the defence of the UK through two World Wars, subsequent world conflicts, the ‘Cold War’ and general air operations. 
Squadron History 
In the Beginning 
Following the issue of a Special Army Order, dated 28th February 1911, the Air Battalion of the Royal Engineers was formed on 1st April 1911, comprising No.1 (Airship) Company and No.2 (Aeroplane) Company. The creation of No.2 Company, stationed at Larkhill, marked the first formation of a British military unit composed of heavier-than-air flying machines. No.2 Company continued flying training including participation in the Army’s Autumn (1911) manoeuvres. 
The Royal Flying Corps The Royal Flying Corps (RFC) was formed on 13 May 1912 by absorbing the Air Battalion’s No.1 and No.2 Companies, with No.2 Company being renamed No.3 Squadron (Military Wing) RFC. On the outbreak of World War 1 the Squadron deployed to France as part of the British Expeditionary Force (BEF) in August 1914 on reconnaissance, photography and artillery spotting duties. In October 1917 Sopwith Camels were received, and the Squadron became a fighter / scout unit. After the Armistice, the Squadron was reduced to cadre strength until re-established at Ambala (India) from January 1920 to September 1921. 
The Biplane Era 
After returning to UK the Squadron spent the 1920s on many short periods at various locations before arriving at Upavon in 1924 with Sopwith Snipes. During their ten-year stay, the Squadron flew Woodcocks, Gamecocks and Bulldogs. The Bulldog was deployed to Sudan during the Abyssinian crisis in 1935. Upon its return from Sudan, No. 3 Squadron introduced the Gladiator into the RAF which became the last biplane operated by the Squadron and as the Second World War started converted to the Hurricane at Biggin Hill. 
World War 2 
A brief period with the BEF in France was followed by relocation to Scotland on night-patrol duties. During 1943, the Squadron replaced the Hurricanes with Typhoons and switched to the anti-shipping and intruder roles. After re-equipping with Tempests in 1944, the Squadron destroyed 288 V1 flying bombs, and following D-Day in 1944 moved on to the Continent as part of the advance towards Germany. 
The Jet Era 
The Squadron remained in Germany, converting successively to the Vampire in 1948, the Sabre in 1953 and the Hunter in 1956. After disbanding (1957 –1959) a brief time with Javelin fighters was followed by an extended period of Canberra B(I)8 operations, before the Squadron converted to the Harrier early in 1972 at Wildenrath. In 1977 the unit moved to Gutersloh near the old East German border, before relocating to Laarbruch with the Harrier GR7. 
Following the closure of RAF Laarbruch, the Squadron returned to the UK in 1999, to RAF Cottesmore. Subsequently, No. 3 Squadron, along with its sister RAF Harrier and Royal Navy Sea Harrier units, combined to form Joint Force Harrier and undertook several deployments including on-board HMS Illustrious during operations in Sierra Leone. The Harrier aircraft of No 3 Squadron also saw action in Kosovo, Bosnia-Herzegovina and both of the Iraq conflicts. 
Farewell to the Harrier 
On the 31 March 2006, the Squadron relinquished its Harrier role and moved to RAF Coningsby becoming the third RAF, and first front-line Squadron to be equipped with the Eurofighter Typhoon. The Squadron’s Typhoons continue to contribute to the RAF’s on-going commitments in Iraq & Syria plus participating in the Falkland Islands detachments and QRA (Quick Reaction Alert) to the present day. 
The date of dedication is May 12th 2023, a date which closely commemorates the 111th Anniversary of the Squadron’s inclusion in the Royal Flying Corps in 1912. 
Symbolism 
There are two faces to the memorial, the aspect facing the Armed Forces Memorial carries the Squadron’s battle honours, while the other side records the time line of its origin in 1911 and its status as recorded in official Air Ministry records. Both aspects carry the Squadron badge with the inscription ‘Tertius Primus Erit’ – The Third Will Be First. The central image is of a cockatrice mounted on a monolith, said to represent a fallen stone from Stonehenge. A cockatrice is a mythical beast that is hatched by a serpent from an egg laid by a rooster, and reputedly able to kill at a glance. The frontal aspect carries two smaller badges, one representing the first location of Larkhill on Salisbury Palin in 1912. Again, the stones symbolise the Squadron’s location of nearby Stonehenge. The second badge is carried on the Typhoon FGR4, which commenced operations in 2006.

36th Ulster Division. The memorial commemorates the actions of the 36th (Ulster) Division during the First World War. The 36th (Ulster) Division, formed in September 1914 under Kitchener’s ‘New Army’ recruitment initiative, played a vital role in the Great War. Commanded initially by Major General C H Powell C.B., the Division was made up from units of the Ulster Volunteer Force, which had been formed in 1913 to fight against Home Rule in Ireland. After initial training in Ireland, Seaford and Aldershot, the Division was deployed to France in September 1915 under the command of Major General Oliver Nugent C.B. D.S.O. The 36th (Ulster) Division took part in the long awaited ‘Big Push’– the Battle of the Somme - commencing on 1 July 1916. Remarkably, progressing as far as the German Third Line, they were the farthest advances made on the day. However, the Division subsequently got caught in German enfilade (flanking) fire from the side and from behind and with the possibility of being cut off with limited supplies they withdrew and were relieved the following day having suffered heavy causalities. The bravery and exploits of the Division are legendary - seeing action in many of the subsequent campaigns of the Western Front until the Armistice in November 1918. The Division ceased all military action at the end of June 1919 when the last soldiers were de-mobbed. It is estimated that The Great War cost 36th (Ulster) Division 32,186 men killed, wounded or missing. The memorial comprises a large, rustic, black granite stone on a base plinth with a black polished façade inscribed with gold lettering. The stone’s rugged profile, suggesting the toughness of the men who fought in the 36th (Ulster) Division, is emphasised by the lines of the polished face. The heraldic Red Hand of Ulster (depicted: sinister / left), which is the insignia badge of the 36th Division, is featured at the top of the memorial above the following inscription: This memorial is dedicated to the Officers and Men of the 36th (Ulster) Division who fought in the 1st World War and the Nursing and Medical corps who served beside them. At the centre of the memorial is a reproduction of the famous James Prinsep Beadle painting ‘The Attack of the Ulster Division’ depicting a scene on the fist day of the Battle of the Somme (1 July 1916), the original of which hangs in the City Hall, Belfast. The Division’s Western Front campaigns are listed either side of this.
Interestingly, soil from each of Ulster’s nine Counties has been placed within the memorial along with soil from the following battlefield sites: Somme, Messines, Passchendaele, Wytchaete and Polcapelle. In total, nine members of the 36th (Ulster) Division were awarded the Victoria Cross, four of which were awarded for actions during the Battle of the Somme.
Below the central painting is a verse from the poem Remember Them by D. Ross Campbell:
They heard the call, they answered yes,
They proudly wore the battle dress,
For us who live they gave their all
That our great flag would never fall.
The base of the memorial displays the inscription: At the going down of the sun and in the morning we will remember them, whilst the reverse notes the memorial was funded by the 36th (Ulster) Division Memorial Association.
Footnote:
The famous Ulster Tower memorial (based on Helen's Tower in Clandboye near Belfast), which dominates the skyline around the village of Thiepval in Northern France, occupies the site of what was the German Front Line and is opposite Thiepval Wood where the 36th (Ulster) Division made its historic charge on the first day of the Battle of the Somme.

ARCTIC CONVOYS
Arctic Convoys - Russian Convoys 
This memorial of black Aberdeen granite was dedicated on 14 August 2012 in honour of all who sailed on the Arctic Convoys during the Second World War. 
The memorial’s inscription is engraved in both English and Russian. Between June 1941 and May 1945, the United Kingdom supplied Russia with millions of tons of war-related goods. These convoys were protected by Royal Navy ships of many types, with only 22 losses. Men serving on these ships undertook this most hazardous journey through seas littered with floes and bergs with force nine and 11 winds whipping the seas into mountainous waves. It was always cold, both inside and out, with the permanent duty of ice breaking from the superstructure to prevent them from capsizing and sinking. The convoys suffered constant attack from the German Navy and Air Force from their safe ports in Norway. Winston Churchill called it “The worst journey in the world”. This is the only major memorial at the Arboretum paid for by one family: the Coyle Family. The adjacent tree is dedicated to Michael Joseph Coyle who served on Royal Navy ships escorting the merchant vessels to Russian ports. Millions of tons of war-related goods were supplied to Russia to help in their conflict against Germany. These supplies had to be carried by sea to Archangel or Murmansk. The convoys of merchant ships had to be guarded by the Royal Navy from attack by German naval and air forces. Weather conditions were usually very poor with frequent heavy seas and sub-zero temperatures. Winston Churchill called it ‘The worst journey in the world.’ The laser-engraved main image shows a British warship navigating in a stormy sea. Also shown are badges of the Arctic Convoy Club and the Russian Convoy Club. Script on the memorial is engraved in both English and Russian. The terms Russian Convoys or Murmansk Convoys could also be used for search purposes. 
The Arctic convoys of WW2 sailed from the United Kingdom, Iceland, and North America to northern ports in the Soviet Union – primarily Arkhangelsk (Archangel) and Murmansk. 
There were 78 convoys between August 1941 and May 1945 
About 1,400 merchant ships delivered essential supplies to the Soviet Union under the Anglo-Soviet agreement and US Lend-Lease program, escorted by ships of the Royal Navy, Royal Canadian Navy and U.S. Navy 
85 merchant vessels and 16 Royal Navy warships (two cruisers, six destroyers, eight other escort ships) were lost. 
In some books the Arctic Convoys are referred to as the Russian Arctic Convoys or the Murmansk Run

Army Commandos Map Index
The British Commandos were first formed by the Army in June 1940, during the Second World War, as a well-armed but non-regimental raider force, employing unconventional and irregular tactics to assault, disrupt and reconnoitre the enemy in mainland Europe, Scandinavia, North Africa, The Levant (Eastern Mediterranean) and the Far East.Initially raids were made by comparatively small numbers, were of short duration and at night but later growing in complexity and size. The Commandos were formed and operated in secrecy and produced a demoralising effect on German coastal forces while achieving celebrity status among the British public, comparable with that attached to fighter pilots, and shrouded in myth. This memorial consists of a reproduction of part of the Association badge – the wreath in copper and the Fairbairn-Sykes fighting knife in stainless steel. The impressive piece was created at Anwick Forge in Lincolnshire and dedicated in the presence of HRH Prince Philip, The Duke of Edinburgh, in July 2007. At the centre of the memorial is a stone with the names of eight commandos awarded the Victoria Cross. Behind the memorial is a roll of honour listing all 1,205 commandos who died in training or on operations during the Second World War. On examination of the Roll of Honour you will note that many were executed: this is because on capture they were executed under the terms of the infamous Hitler “Kommandobefehl” Commando Order.

Association of WRENS Centenary Stone. The installation of the AOW Centenary Stone took place on Wednesday 23rd September 2020 in the WRNS Garden.The memorial represents one hundred years since the Association was formed and it is very fitting that installation was able to go ahead in what should have been a year of celebration when so many planned events had to be cancelled.
The stone was constructed by Robyn Golden-Hann. It represents not only former wrens but also the Women of the Royal Naval Services as they are today. The WRNS were founded in l9l7 to support the men of the Royal Navy, but were disbanded in 1919. In 1939, at the outbreak of WW2, they were re-established and remained in service until 1993 when they were fully integrated into the Royal Navy. Women now carry out exactly the same duties as their male counterparts, both at sea and ashore. The garden is dedicated to all who served in the service and is designed to encourage birds, insects and butterflies. The pathways form the shape of an anchor. The wren, which was carved by the Essex Woodcarvers, forms part of a memorial for the 21 WRNS and a Naval Nursing Sister who lost their lives when their ship, SS Aguila, was torpedoed inl94l. One of the first WRNS to see active service was Wendy Clayin, who in 1990, served on board HMS Brilliant. The Women’s Royal Naval Service (WRNS), known as the Wrens, was formed in 1917 to release Royal Navy men for sea service during the First World War. It was disbanded after the war. On 11th April 1939 Vera Laughton Matthews was appointed Director of the newly reformed Women’s Royal Naval Service WRNS: she had previously been a member during World War 1. It was originally envisaged that there would be about 3000 women in the WRNS, however at its peak the number was more than 65,000. Around 75,000 Wrens carried out highly confidential and responsible roles in Britain and overseas. The WRNS was fully integrated into the Royal Navy in 1993.
This charming garden at the far end of the Royal Naval Review is dedicated to the WRNS and has been designed to encourage birds, insects and butterflies. The paths are in the shape of an anchor. Buddleia shrubs provide a haven for butterflies in summer. The two rose beds are planted with “Wren” roses to celebrate the 90th anniversary of the Association of Wrens 1917 – 2007. Notcutts Nurseries developed this rose for the 2007 Chelsea Flower Show and donated plants to the Wrens Garden at the NMA. In the rose beds and against the trees may be found dedications to individual Wrens. Located in the garden is the Aguila Memorial, a beautifully carved wren which commemorates the 21 WRNS and one Naval Nursing Sister who were lost when SS Aguila was torpedoed in 1941 (see M-152 Aguilla Memorial).

Text:
BATTLE OF THE RIVER PLATE (The first sea battle of WW2)
The Battle of the River Plate, which took place on the 13 December 1939, was the first major naval battle of the Second World War and the only episode of the War to take place in South America. The German pocket battleship Admiral Graf Spee, commanded by Kapitän sur See Hans Langsdorff, had been terrorising Allied shipping in the South Atlantic. It was eventually tracked down and engaged by three ships from the Royal Navy’s South American division (the cruisers HMS Ajax, HMS Exeter, and HMS Achilles) commanded by Commodore Henry Harwood Harwood. All four ships sustained considerable damage and Graf Spee limped into an estuary in neutral Uruguay to undertake necessary repairs. Given just 72 hours to repair, the Germans knew escape was impossible and scuttled (sank) the ship in the River Plate. Two days later, in Buenos Aires where the crew were taken, Kapitän Langsdorff committed suicide. He was buried there with full military honours and the service was attended by British officers who were present in the city. This impressive black granite memorial was unveiled in the presence of the few remaining River Plate veterans on 12 April 2014 to mark the 75th anniversary of the Battle of the River Plate. Significantly, it was the 300th memorial to be dedicated at the Arboretum. 
The Graf Spee was a German battleship; her mission, to destroy allied merchant ships in the Atlantic. 
In December 1940 she was engaged by HM Ships Exeter, Ajax and Achilles 
Exeter was badly damaged and withdrew; the other two ships, although damaged, remained on station. 
The Graf Spee put into Montevideo, Uruguay, which was a neutral country, so she could only stay for 24 hours for humanitarian reasons; however, she managed to stay for 72 hours. 
The Admiralty sent a signal to Ajax and Achilles informing them that a carrier and a battlecruiser were on their way as support; this was in fact one of the greatest deceptions of the war, they were not. 
Graf Spee's captain, convinced that stronger forces were waiting, left the majority of his crew behind and sailed out of the port where he scuttled his ship; he committed suicide two days later. 
Most of his crew stayed in Montevideo, others went to Buenos Aires, many of them married and raised families; the last surviving crew member, died in Buenos Aires June 2007 aged 89. 
The apron approaching the memorial shows the exact size of the shells that were exchanged. 
The front of the memorial shows the crests and silhouettes of the 3 RN ships, the reverse side is the ship's crest and silhouette of the Graf Spee. 
There are two quotes from Winston Churchill; "This brilliant sea fight takes its place in our naval annals and in long cold dark winter it warms the cockles of the British hearts"; and other one says, "This great battle will long be told in song and story" 
Behind the memorial is a small pavier with the inscription, "sealed herein are the names of those who served on HMS Ajax, HMS Achilles, HMS Exeter and Admiral Graf Spee who gave their lives whilst serving their country. Also, those who 75 years later supported the commissioning and dedication of this memorial on 12 April 2014.

Bevin Boys
Nearly 48,000 young men, all of them conscripts, joined regular miners in their work from 1943 - 1948. They were pressed into action because many miners had gone to war and at one stage coal reserves fell to less than three weeks' supply.  Ernest Bevin was the Minister of Labour at that time and decreed that every 10th man called up for war service would instead be sent down the coal mines.  The Bevin Boys were chosen out of a hat. Every month, for 20 months, Bevin's secretary drew numbers from his distinctive Homburg hat. If the number drawn matched the last digit of a man's National Service number, he was sent to the mines 
Comedian Eric Morecambe was a Bevin Boy (as was Brian Rix and Nat Lofthouse). 
The work was unfamiliar and dangerous; resulting in many injuries and lives lost. They were also often unfairly accused of being ‘Conscientious Objectors’, which they most certainly were not, although some Conscientious Objectors HAD been sent to work in the mines as an alternative to imprisonment. 
The plinths are made of Kilkenny limestone which will eventually turn black, like coal. 
During the Second World War 48,000 men were conscripted, via a lottery, to work in coal mines 
They were called “Bevin Boys” after Ernest Bevin, the Minister of Labour and National Service in the wartime coalition government 
The Bevin Boys joined regular miners in their dirty, dangerous but essential work to keep the coal supplies of Britain flowing 
The badge awarded to Bevin Boys can be seen on the face of the main memorial 
The smaller of the two blocks is carved with the tools and equipment used by the Bevin Boys 
There are also two mice carved on the memorial as Bevin Boys said that there were always mice in the mines. Can you spot them?

Brigade of Gurkhas Memorial. Gurkhas have served the British Crown for over 200 years. It is a rich heritage marked by excellence and sacrifice. The names of over 400 Gurkhas appear on the Armed Forces Memorial. The history of the Brigade from its inception in 1815 during the early wars between the Honourable East India Company and city-state of Gorkha, through the early Afghan wars, the two World Wars, the almost continuous post-war conflicts to modern day Afghanistan, is forged from the deep feeling of mutual respect and admiration developed between the British and their Gurkha adversaries. Following the Nepal Wars, and under the terms of the Sugauli Peace Treaty in 1816, Gurkhas were permitted to volunteer for service in the East India Company’s Army. From these volunteers were formed the first regiments of the Gurkha Brigade,and from this time stems Britain’s friendship with Nepal, a country which has proved a staunch ally ever since and has become our ‘oldest ally’ in Asia. Since 1997, the Brigade of Gurkhas has been operationally and battle proven in Bosnia, Kosovo, East Timor, Sierra Leone, Macedonia and Iraq. With 11 years of continuous Gurkha deployments in Afghanistan, the human cost and sacrifice in Afghanistan has been high. Fifty four officers and soldiers of the Brigade have been wounded in action and 15 have died.
The memorial takes the form of a traditional chautara, a traditional resting place for travellers on hillside trails in Nepal. The plaque incorporates the badges of the units of the Brigade, past and present.

Text:
British Nuclear Veterans Memorial
The BNTVA Formed in 1983, the British Nuclear Test Veterans Association (BNTVA) is a focus for all those who served at the test sites and combines comradeship with the objective of recognition of the ill effects suffered by some veterans, their families and children born with lung problems. The BNTVA believe that over 22,000 British servicemen from the Army, Royal Air Force, Royal Navy, Merchant Navy, and Royal Fleet Auxiliary participated in the British and American nuclear tests and clean-ups between 1952-1966, along with scientists from the Atomic Weapons Research Establishment and civilians. The BNTVA promote research into the effects of clastogenic radiation on the nuclear community, and educate the general public about the nuclear tests in creative ways.
The BNTVA has about 1,400 members of which one third are widows. Membership is limited to men who served in the nuclear test areas, their widows and their descendants.
The Nuclear Test Program
Between 1952 and 1958 21 atmospheric tests took place at the locations listed on the memorial. The yield from these tests varied between 1 and 150 kilotons.
3rd October 1952: the Hurricane Test at Monte Bello
15th & 23rd October 1953: 2 Totem Tests at Emu Field
16 May & 19th June 1956: 2 Mozaic Tests at Monte Bello
September-October 1956: 4 tests in the Buffalo series at Maralinga
May – June 1957: 3 tests in the Grapple series at Malden Island
September –October 1957: 3 tests in the Antler series at Maralinga.
November 1957 – September 1958: 6 tests in the Grapple Series at Christmas Island.
From the 1960s further tests were undertaken at underground facilities in Nevada in cooperation with the USA.
The Medal for British Nuclear Test Veterans
The BNTVA campaigned for many years for a medal to be awarded to recognise the service and sacrifice of the service personnel who had taken part in the tests.
At a ceremony at the BNTVA Memorial on 21st November 2022 the Prime Minister Rishi Sunak announced that the British Nuclear Veterans would now be entitled to a medal to mark their service and said: “I am incredibly proud that we are able to mark the service and dedication of our nuclear test veterans with this new medal. Their commitment and service has preserved peace for the past 70 years, and it is only right their contribution to our safety, freedom and way of life is appropriately recognised with this honour.
This medal is an enduring symbol of our country’s gratitude to each and every person who played a part in this effort and their loved ones who supported them.”
HM Government website states that:
The Nuclear Test Medal will be a commemorative medal that can be worn by recipients.
The medal also recognises the contribution made by veterans and civilians from across Australia, New Zealand, Fiji and Kiribati. All service personnel and civilians under UK command, including close partners from the Commonwealth and Pacific region, who participated in, or were present at, the British or American nuclear tests at the Montebello Islands, Christmas Island, Malden Island and Maralinga & Emu Field, South Australia between 1952 and 1967 will be eligible for the medal. This also includes scientists and local employees.
It is estimated that around 22,000 veterans will be eligible for the medal.

Burma Railway Memorial. This 30-metre stretch of track was bought back from Burma to form the memorial here at the National Memorial Arboretum. Construction started in June 1942 and after 18 months the 415km (257 miles) of railway was finished. The POW’s and Asian labourers, many of whom were Indians who had gone to Burma to work for the British, had to work long hours in extreme conditions and with little food. Over 330,000 men worked on the railway. Around 16,000 POW’s and 100,000 labourers lost their lives. It has been said that one person died for each sleeper that was laid. Burma railway actually took 16 months to build, 2 months faster than engineers estimated. This was because the Japanese pushed the workers to the absolute limit. The railway ran between Bangkok in Thailand to Rangoon in Burma, 600 bridges had to be constructed and bridge number 277 was the infamous bridge over the River Kwai. When this piece of track arrived here one of our Volunteers traced its origins only to find that it was actually manufactured in Middlesbrough! (There are embossed markings on the inside of the left-hand rail, just past the 9th sleeper).

The 15ft tall monolith is a copy of the one that stands at the Commonwealth War Grave Cemetery in Kohima, on the border of India with Burma, which saw some of the fiercest fighting of the Burma campaign, but is where the Japanese advance was finally halted.
It is intended to pay tribute to ALL organisations, armed forces and individuals who hold either the Burma Campaign Star or the Pacific Star with Burma Clasp. On the memorial is the famous Kohima Epitaph that has been used around the world on memorials and at remembrance services:
‘WHEN YOU GO HOME
TELL THEM OF US AND SAY
FOR YOUR TOMORROW
WE GAVE OUR TODAY’
The words are attributed to John Maxwell Edmonds (1875 -1958), an English Classicist, who had put them together among a collection of 12 epitaphs for World War One, in 1916. According to the Burma Star Association the words were used for the Kohima Memorial as a suggestion by Major John Etty-Leal, the GSO II of the 2nd Division, another classical scholar. The verse is thought to have been inspired by the Greek lyric poet Simonides of Ceos (556-468 BC) who wrote after the Battle of Thermopylae in 480 BC:
"Go tell the Spartans, thou that passesth by, That faithful to their precepts here we lie."

Changi Lych Gate. This is the original Lych Gate from Changi Jail, Singapore, designed by Captain C.D. Pickersgill and built in 1942 by Royal Engineers from the 18th Division who were prisoners of war. The gate was first erected at the entrance to the camp cemetery to mark the graves of those who had died and to give their funerals some dignity. In 1952, the graves were moved to Kranji War Memorial Cemetery and the Lych Gate to the British Garrison Church, St George’s, in Singapore. When British troops withdrew completely from Singapore in 1971, the Lych Gate was dismantled and brought back to England where it was erected at the Queen’s Division Depot, Bassingbourn Barracks in Royston, Hertfordshire. In 2003, the refurbished Lych Gate was reconstructed at the Arboretum by the 39th Engineering Regiment and the re-dedication took place on 8 February 2004. In the structure of the Lych Gate was carved the national emblems of the British Isles. Inside the eaves, in Gothic lettering, is an inscription:
‘To the Glory of God
And in memory of those
Who laid down their lives
For their King and Country’.
The idea of a Lych Gate, familiar to prisoners from churchyards back in England, gave some feeling of dignity and respect for those who had died in appalling conditions. The Lych Gate is set in an area heavy with symbolism. It is the entrance now to the Far East Prisoners of War Grove. The Cheshire Yeomanry Memorial
'Moving Forward, Looking Back' 
This memorial was commissioned to coincide with the 225th anniversary of the raising of the Cheshire Yeomanry Regiment. With the constant uncertainties of future British Army structures and the unknown future threats of town planning, what better place to secure our memorial, for future generations of Cheshire Yeomen, than at the National Memorial Arboretum. We now have a permanent and fitting place to lay our wreaths and pay our respects to all our comrades. We have a focal point to be able to contemplate those that have gone before us. 
The Cheshire Yeomanry was raised as a light cavalry regiment in 1797 under the threat of a Napoleonic invasion. The regiment has built a proud history during that period. Our role remains today as Light Cavalry and throughout its early history up to and during World War 2 the regiment served with its constant companion, the horse. Since then, we have had another type of companion, who has been our protection, our weapon, our shelter and our means of transport, the mechanised vehicle. Our memorial represents the strength and power of a horse, but at the same time represents through its design, examples of many of those other vehicles. 
Designer and Sculptor - Joanne Risley (Sculptor) 
“I was very honoured to have been chosen to create the memorial sculpture for the Cheshire Yeomanry to celebrate 225 years since its inception. In response to the brief, I have designed a life-sized rearing war horse created using the mechanisms, structure and detail found on the Fox, Ferret and Jackal armoured vehicles. 
Objects of war mix with more familiar domestic objects such as a spade and the beloved ‘BV’ boiling vessel that provides the crew with hot water for tea and cooking. The plinth carries a turret wheel which frames the cast bronze regimental crest. I have tried to encapsulate the strength and dynamism of the animal with the armoured feel of the regiment’s vehicles. 
The arboretum already features a highly naturalistic life-size horse so I wanted to create a unique and modern monument that would strike a different note. The regiment kindly provided historic context, photographic material and access to Fox Barracks where I was able to study one of the Jackal vehicles up close. At the Cheshire Military Museum the Fox and Ferret armoured vehicles provided further inspiration. 
The body of the horse is tank-like and incorporates toeholds, wheel arches, rear lights and smoke canisters. The legs and thighs are formed from wheels and tyre treads with the helmet-like head supported by gun parts and a spine and ribs derived from the Jackal anti-roll system. 
The whole sculpture stands 3m tall. Created from weathering steel, which contains copper and smaller bronze elements, the overall appearance will take on a rusted and aged appearance whilst the material’s unique properties provide a protective surface that will endure indefinitely. 
As well as being of symbolic and emotional importance to the regiment, the horse embodies courage, freedom, power, endurance, personal drive, passion and heroism. The animal appears to be moving forward but looking back in order to represent soldiers of the regiment past and present. 
Joanne Risley studied Fine Art at Mid-Cheshire College, Duncan of Jordanstone College of Art and then at The University of Ulster. 
She was elected a member of Manchester Academy of Fine Art in 2017. www.joannerisley.co.uk 
Materials Used - Rusted Corten steel, copper, and smaller bronze elements. 
Age of Memorial - The build was completed during 2021 and installed at the NMA in June 2022 and a dedication ceremony was held 12th June 2022. 
Symbolism - The Memorial has been created to allow visitors to remember those lost and to contemplate, surrounded by the memorials of all Yeomanry Regiments and positioned so that there is a full view from all angles of Yeomanry Avenue.

Chindits Memorial. An obelisk in memory of the multi-national force which became known as ‘The Chindits’. They were formed and led by Major General Orde Wingate DSO. The Chindits operated deep behind enemy lines in North Burma in the War against Japan with the intention of preventing supplies being transported to the battlefront. For many months they lived in and fought the enemy in the jungles, totally relying on airdrops for their supplies. They had some successes but suffered greatly from the climate and constant shortage of supplies. Few of them were fit for further service after emerging from the jungle.▪ Listed on brass plaques affixed to the sides are those regiments and units from which the Chindits drew personnel.

Civil Defence George Cross Awards
This memorial commemorates the 12 men awarded the George Cross for outstanding bravery while engaged in Civil Defence work. Ten recipients, who were Civil Defenders during WWII, are also commemorated by a blue plaque, erected on 30th June 2007, by an oak tree behind this memorial. 
Nine men were awarded the George Cross for Fire and Rescue duties that frequently involved burrowing through burning buildings in danger of further collapse; in fact the first individual to be awarded the George Cross was Thomas Hopper Alderson who was part of this group. 
Three men were awarded the George Cross for bomb disposal work, one of whom, Charles Howard was killed when the bomb on which he was working blew up. For security reasons the citation for these three men sometimes read “For conspicuous bravery in carrying out dangerous duties”. 
Two men, Frederick Davies and George Henderson, were Civil Defenders who have been awarded the George Cross for gallantry since World War II. George Henderson was a Gibraltar fireman who received a posthumous award for his gallantry: for this reason a piece of stone from the Rock of Gibraltar has been placed in the memorial. 
The memorial was unveiled on 18th June 2011 by Jim Beaton GC, Chairman of the VC and GC Association. Jim Beaton’s own award was for the defence of Princess Anne when she was attacked in the Mall in 1974.

"Operation Frankton"
"The Cockleshell Heroes"
Located in the Allied Special Forces Memorial Grove is a seat in the shape of a Canoe which
commemorates the men of Royal Marine Boom Patrol Detachment – later known as the “Cockleshell Heroes”. On the night of 7 December 1942, ten Royal Marine Commandos climbed out of the submarine “HMS Tuna” and were launched into five two-man canoes. Their destination was Bordeaux Harbour and their mission was to destroy as many ships as possible using limpet mines which attach below the water line. This audacious raid was a success. However, some marines were lost in the icy cold waters of the Gironde estuary on the route in, and others were captured and executed by the Germans. Only two Marines survived the mission. This memorial is linked to the Phantom Memorial Garden located beside the Aspects Centre.
This memorial was designed by Mike Colton.
Dedicated in 2013. The memorial comprises a wooden seat in the symbolic shape of a 15ft. by 2ft. 6in. Cockle Mark II canoe, as used by the Royal Marines during "Operation Frankton" in 1942. This seat and the two memorial plaques commemorate the Royal Marines who took part and the French civilians who assisted them during their attempted escape after the successful raid. Behind the canoe is a large metal relief picture of the Marines leaving HMS Tuna which was a practice casting before the Bronze Memorial which sits at the 'Cockleshell Heroes' memorial at St. Genes de Blaye in France was made.

In the first 6 months of the Second World War some 1,900 ships had been defensively equipped and by the end of 1940, a total of 3,400 were armed.
Guns were manned by personnel from Maritime Royal Artillery, Royal Navy and Royal Marines.
Their primary role was defence against surfaced U-boats and aircraft.
The 40mm Bofors gun was one of the types of gun fitted to merchant ships, used mainly as an Anti-Aircraft weapon. Some merchant ships had larger 3-inch or 6-inch guns fitted.
Defensively Equipped Merchant Ships (DEMS)

They fought off enemy aircraft, mine, submarine and surface attacks to ensure that the merchant ships could carry supplies to services and civilians.

The Far East Prisoners of War (FEPOW) Grove is approached through the Changi Lych Gate, originally constructed at the POW Cemetery in Singapore. Half of the approximately 50,000 British servicemen captured by the Japanese in the Second World War were forced to work on the Burma/Thai Railway. Other FEPOWs worked building airfields and roads, and many were transported to Japan to work in mines, shipbuilding yards and other heavy industries. Approximately 800 British POWs were amongst those who built a railway in Sumatra.
Most of the trees in the Grove are dedicated to individual FEPOWs from all three services and to internees. Other trees relate to groups of FEPOWs and four of these are worthy of special mention: The estimated 1,000 UK FEPOWs who died in North Borneo, principally on the “Death Marches”. Memorial: Far East Prisoners of War Memorial Building
Text:
THE FEPOW MEMORIAL BUILDING 
Fundraising for the museum started on the 15th February 2002, the 60th anniversary of the surrender of Singapore to the Japanese, which is when the majority of FEPOWs were captured. The majority of funding was raised by an organisation called COFEPOW (Children of Far East Prisoners of War). COFEPOW came about after a lady named Carol Cooper, from Norfolk, read an article in a newspaper in 1994, concerning the diary of a former prisoner-of-war of the Japanese. She realised that this was the diary of her father who went to fight in the Far East when she was only 2 years old but had died working on the Burma railway.
▪ After receiving a transcript of the diary, she went to Burma in an attempt to find his grave. Her journey was made into a documentary by the BBC. Many other children and relatives of such prisoners then contacted Carol and COFEPOW was formed in 1997. It took 3½ years to raise the funds, the same amount of time that the FEPOWs spent in the horrendous conditions of the prison camps. The building was officially opened on VJ Day 2005 the 60th anniversary of the end of the war in South East Asia. It is designed to take the shape of a prison hut. Inside there are exhibits and artefacts covering the experiences of the servicemen and civilians who were taken prisoner. In the far right-hand corner of the museum is a copy of the Java Windows. These are replicas of the two made by a British Naval officer whilst a prisoner]and were situated in a small chapel that the Japanese allowed them to have, mainly for propaganda purposes. A close inspection of the British coat of arms will reveal that the lion has the face of Winston Churchill. Knowing that their captors had not discovered this helped to keep up morale. The original windows still survive today and can be found in All Saints Church in Jakarta, Indonesia. Also, look for the names being projected onto the wall at the end of the museum. This is a list of all those who were imprisoned, including the survivors and you can search for individual names using the touch screen. On another touch screen, data held by the Commonwealth War Graves Commission can be accessed.

Memorial: Fleet Air Arm Memorial (FLY Navy Federation)
Text:
FLEET AIR ARM 
British naval flying started in 1909, with the construction of an airship for naval duties. In 1911 the Royal Navy graduated its first aeroplane pilots at the Royal Aero Club flying ground at RAF Eastchurch. 
In 1912, naval and army aviation were combined to become the Royal Flying Corps (RFC). The Naval Wing of the RFC lasted until July 1914 when the Royal Navy reformed its air branch, under the Air Department of the Admiralty, naming it the Royal Naval Air Service (RNAS). 
By the outbreak of the First World War, in August 1914, the RNAS had more aircraft under its control than the remaining RFC. The roles of the RNAS were fleet reconnaissance, patrolling coasts for enemy ships and submarines and attacking enemy coastal territory. 
In April 1918 the RNAS, which at this time had 67,000 officers and men, 2,949 aircraft, 103 airships and 126 coastal stations, merged with the RFC to form the Royal Air Force. 
In 1924, the Fleet Air Arm of the Royal Air Force was formed, encompassing those RAF units that normally embarked on aircraft carriers and fighting ships. The year was significant for British naval aviation as only weeks before the founding of the Fleet Air Arm, the Royal Navy had commissioned HMS Hermes, the world's first ship to be designed and built as an aircraft carrier. 
In 2009 the Royal Navy celebrated the centenary of Naval Aviation, and the memorial honours the sacrifice made by 6,749 men and women who gave their lives in the service of naval aviation over those 100 years. 
Over 80% of front-line Fleet Air Arm Squadrons are currently deployed on operations round the world. 
The memorial is a sculptured plinth of Portland Stone supporting a granite aircraft carrier. The inscription on the base is taken from Psalm 139 in the Bible

Free Spirit Horse Memorial
A tribute to the unique contribution made by horses throughout history in times of War. Recognising their continuing service to humankind in Work, Rehabilitation, Education, Sport and Leisure. In 2013 a group of people with a love of horses came together with a vision to create a memorial acknowledging the horse’s unfaltering service to humankind and to celebrate the unique relationship between horses and humans that exists through sport, history, work, rehabilitation, education and leisure. This beautiful sculpture and its carefully planned setting were unveiled in 2019, made possible through generous donations and the work of local craftspeople who contributed their skills to realising the vision of Free Spirit.
Free Spirit is a unique project that embodies the inclusiveness that is reflected in the non-judgmental partnership between horse and human. Gartmore Riding School in Hammerwich and many contributors raised funds to create a life-sized bronze statue acknowledging the horse’s unfaltering service to humanity, to be displayed at the National Memorial Arboretum, Staffordshire. There are few people left today that remember the essential role the horse played through history and how until a generation ago the horse was part of everyday life. The memorial expresses endurance, service and partnership and represents determination and trust, inspiration for which came from young people. The project brought together individuals from all ages and backgrounds sharing the importance of the horse to different generations, ethnicities and religions. The groundwork has been carefully designed to welcome all visitors, regardless of mobility or disability, allowing all members of society to enjoy the memorial together. The provision of spaces between the seats creates multiple points of access for wheelchair users; a lower plinth height and plaques incorporating Braille and Makaton allow the visually impaired to enjoy the memorial through a tactile experience. Free Spirit brought the essential contribution that the horse has made to humanity to new audiences and generations in a number of projects, including art, music and history, and worked across the local community and beyond. The opportunity to meet a pony has never been easily accessible to many of the young people visiting by the project, and Free Spirit recognises that the unique relationship between horse and human can increase confidence and self-esteem, and that this connection leaves a legacy that continues to bring joy to this and future generations. The horse is part of our story, and the people involved in its inception and creation were particularly proud to see so many young people engaging with the project. Inspired by the thoughts and feelings of these young people, Birmingham songwriter Dominic Malin wrote a signature song for Free Spirit. The song embraces the qualities associated with the horse and the music reflects the past, engages with the present and carries a message into the future. It is an honour to have horses in our lives and Free Spirit represents this for centuries and generations to come.

GENERAL POST OFFICE MEMORIAL GARDEN
In the first half of the 20th Century, the Post Office was the largest peacetime state employer in the United Kingdom, responsible for operating the postal, telephone and telegraph services. In wartime its staff had to rise to the immense challenge of meeting both civil and military communication requirements. Many transferred to the armed services where they often applied their experience and skills to communication work. 
In 1939 73,000 GPO workers were called into the services, just when mobilisation and evacuation caused millions of people to change address, so increasing the amount of mail posted and the problems of delivering it during the blackout. Post Offices played a key role by distributing millions of ration books, public information leaflets, and paying out allowances. 
GPO staff served in all arms of the fighting forces and 3,800 of them died. 
The path is laid out in the shape of the Royal Mail insignia. 
The older EIIR pillar boxes are from the period 1952 - 1991 and ‘Royal Mail’ appeared on them first in 1991. All have the crowns of the relevant Sovereign at the time. There are boxes for Edward VII and George VI. 
The green Victorian wall post box was blown out of its wall in Deptford, London during the blitz - note the damage - but the local people rebuilt the wall and replaced the box to keep the service running.

Glider Pilot Regiment
The Regiment was established in 1942 and remained active until 1957, when it was absorbed into the modern Army Air Corps. The Regiment’s motto was “Nothing is impossible”, as the nature of their one way trips required the aircrews to subsequently join in combat operations on the ground. The Regiment’s highly trained aircrew was also used to great effect in covert activity. In the post war years, the Regiment remained active, undertaking liaison and reconnaissance roles in the Light Aircraft Flights operated by the Army. On 1 September 1957, the Regiment disbanded to create the foundation of what was to become the modern Army Air Corps. The memorial stone is sourced from Gelderland in the Netherlands to acknowledge the Regiment’s major role in the Battle of Arnhem.

GUINEA PIG CLUB
The Guinea Pig Club, established in July 1941, was a social club and mutual support network for British and allied aircrew injured during the Second World War. 
Its membership was made up of patients of Sir Archibold McIndoe at Queen Victoria Hospital, East Grinstead, Sussex, who had undergone pioneering reconstructive surgery, generally after receiving burns injuries in aircraft. 
By the end of the Second World War the club had 649 members. 
The memorial, which stands over 2 metres high, is carved from green Cumbrian slate and resembles the shape of a Spitfire wing. 
The design features a crashed Hurricane at the bottom with its vapour trail weaving down from the top. The logo of the Guinea Pig Club is also carved at the top of the memorial. On the left hand side of the design, the meandering vapour trail of the falling Hurricane outlines the strong facial profile of the pioneering plastic surgeon, Sir Archibald McIndoe. 
Along the memorial’s right edge is an inscription “Out of the flames came inspiration” provided by Guinea Pig Dr. Sandy Saunders. The memorial was unveiled by HRH The Duke of Edinburgh, president of the Guinea Pig Club, on 2 November 2016. Index 
The Guinea Pig Club was established in 1941. Its membership was made up of patients of Archibald McIndoe at Queen Victoria Hospital, East Grinstead, Sussex, who had carried out experimental reconstructive plastic surgery on airmen who had received burn injuries in aircraft. The club remained active after the end of the war, and its annual reunion meetings continued until 2007. 
The outline of Archibald McIndoe’s face forms the left side of this memorial. 
The memorial was unveiled in 2016 by the Duke of Edinburgh.

Gulf War 1990-1991 Memorial
This memorial was dedicated in honour of the 47 British personnel who died in the liberation of Kuwait and all those who fought in the Gulf War. The memorial comprises three stainless steel supporting pillars representing each of Britain’s three Armed Forces. The centre stone of the memorial carries the image of the reverse of the Gulf Medal, engraved in black granite. Each of the 47 pavers on the memorial, which are laid out in concentric circles, carries the name of one of the fallen. Beneath the centre stone, there are 48 poppies from the Festival of Remembrance at the Royal Albert Hall in 2015, one poppy for each of the ‘47 fallen’ and one solitary poppy for all of the veterans who have passed away since the Gulf War. The memorial, which is aligned on a compass bearing of 302 degrees from true north - the compass bearing from Kuwait to the Arboretum, carries an inscription in English, Latin and Arabic. The inscription reads: ‘In memory of the 47 fallen comrades, and to all those who fought in Operation Granby (1990-91) - The Liberation of Kuwait, those who subsequently passed away and also those that continued to fight their own battles, long after the guns fell silent. Lest We Forget

Memorial: HM Ships Glorious, Acasta and Ardent Memorial
Text:
HMS Glorious, HMS Acasta & HMS Ardent
The Loss of HMS Glorious, HMS Acasta & HMS Ardent on 8th June 1940. 
Scharnhorst (Kapitain zur See Hoffman) and Gneisenau (Kapitan zur See Netzbandt), during the course of the Kriegsmarine’s Operation Juno, sank the aircraft carrier HMS Glorious (Captain Guy D’Oyly-Hughes DSO, 1159 crew and 59 RAF personnel were lost; only 39 survivors) and her two escorts HMS Acasta (Commander C E Glasfurd, there was only one survivor) and HMS Ardent-H41 (Lt Commander J E Barker, 152 crew killed and the 2 survivors became POW) in somewhat controversial circumstances. 
Why was HMS Glorious detached from the rest of the fleet sailing from Narvik and sailing with only two destroyers for escort? Why didn’t HMS Glorious have aircraft in the air watching for enemy warships? However, HMS Acasta torpedoed the Scharnhorst causing damage that put her out of action for the remainder of the year. 
Admiral Sir Charles Forbes recommended that both Commander Glasfurd and Lieutenant Commander Barker be awarded the Victoria Cross: they were awarded a posthumous Mention in Despatches. 
The first 2 letters of the ships names forms, GLARAC, the name of the association.

HMS ARDENT 
To the left of the Falklands Memorial is the anchor from HMS ARDENT, one of the ships lost in the Falklands conflict. 
Several years prior to the conflict she was anchored in Portland Harbour when a storm blew up and she was in danger of being driven ashore; to prevent this they severed one of her anchors and took her out to sea; the anchor was left on the sea bed. Following the loss of Ardent, Babcock Ltd. raised the anchor, renovated it and donated it to the South Atlantic Medal Association as a tribute and memorial to the ship and crew. 
This memorial is one of the original Anchors from the Type 21 frigate, HMS Ardent. The anchor was lost in a storm in Portland harbour in 1980. 
HMS Ardent was lost in action on 21 May 1982, defending the landings to retake the Falkland Islands. The HMS Ardent association was formed by the survivors. 
The anchor was recovered some years later and offered to the Association as a permanent memorial to all those shipmates who lost their lives in the 
the South Atlantic. The memorial was dedicated on 21 May 2015 in the presence of HRH The Duchess of Gloucester GCVO.

HMS ARGONAUT
Four different ships have carried the name HMS Argonaut, the first was in 1782; the second was a WW1 Cruiser; and the third, a WW2 Cruiser which took part in the D-Day landings in 1944. 
The final Argonaut, a Frigate, took part in the Falklands conflict where it was badly damaged; Able Seaman Iain Boldy and Able Seaman Matthew J Stuart lost their lives. Their names appear on the back of the memorial, as well as on the AFM. 
Margaret Allen, the wife of lain Boldy, was instrumental in the creation of this memorial which shows the ship's crest, under which is part of a poem written by Margaret. 
Four ships named HMS Argonaut have served with the Royal Navy. 
For the last three ships, the names of the crew members who died while serving on the ship are recorded on the reverse face of the memorial. 
The fourth HMS Argonaut (the Leander-class frigate – Pennant Number F56), was commissioned in 1967 and saw service across the world including escorting the RMS Queen Mary on her final voyage to the USA. 
In April 1982, she set sail for the Falkland Islands in the South Atlantic to join the existing naval task force as part of Operation Corporate. The ship was badly damaged while patrolling in San Carlos Bay on 21 May 1982 and two of her crew were lost. 
The memorial is dedicated to all those lost whilst serving on HMS Argonaut and was unveiled on 21 May 2017.

HMS BARHAM MEMORIAL
HMS Barham was a Queen Elizabeth Class Battleship armed with 8 15-inch guns: she was launched on 31st December 1914 and entered service the following year. Most notably she was part of the 5th Battle Squadron at the Battle of Jutland in 1916, when it was attached to Vice Admiral Beaty's Battle Cruiser Squadron. 
She saw extensive service in the first half of WW2 and took part in the Battle of Matapan in March 1941 when the Italian Fleet was defeated. 
On 25th November 1941 she was sunk off the Libyan coast by U-331 
The memorial is dedicated to all crew members of HMS Barham from entering service in 1915 until sinking on 25th November 1941: she served in both world wars. 
She was the fourth ship to be named HMS Barham after Charles Middleton, 1st Lord Barham (1726-1813). He was the 1st Lord of the Admiralty who gave Lord Nelson his orders when he sailed to join the fleet prior to the Battle of Trafalgar. 
HMS Barham was a Queen Elizabeth Class Battleship (27,500 tons) armed with 8 15-inch guns: she was launched on 31st December 1914 and entered service the following year. Most notably she was was part of the 5th Battle Squadron at the Battle of Jutland in 1916, when it was attached to Vice Admiral Beaty's Battle Cruiser Squadron. 
She saw extensive service in the first half of WW2 particularly with the Mediterranean Fleet under the command of Admiral Andrew B Cunningham and took part in the Battle of Matapan on 28th March 1941 when the Italian Fleet was defeated. 
On 25th November 1941 she was sunk off the Libyan coast by U-331: her commanding officer Captain Geoffrey Clement Cooke, 55 officers and 806 ratings were killed. There is a famous sequence of the sinking filmed by a Pathe cameraman aboard HMS Valiant: it is available on the internet.

H.M. Ships Bulwark, Albion, Centaur

HMS CHARYBDIS AND HMS LIMBOURNE
The HMS Charybdis and HMS Limbourne Memorial remembers the 502 sailors, marines and crew who lost their lives when both ships were torpedoed by German destroyers and sunk in the English Channel in October 1943 during Operation Tunnel. 
Operation Tunnel was mounted when the Royal Navy gained intelligence the Germans would be moving a convoy along the Brittany coast on the night of 22nd/23rd October 1943. The cruiser HMS Charybdis accompanied six destroyers should have been a formidable force for the engagement, but it is thought that the German shore-based radar gave the enemy advance warning of the movements of the British ships. Although the Charybdis picked up the approach of enemy ships on her radar, it was too late to anticipate a joint torpedo attack by a group of German destroyers. 
The Charybdis was hit by a torpedo first, and the destroyer HMS Limbourne soon afterwards, both ships sank, and the German ships withdrew, undetected. 
The HMS Charybdis and HMS Limbourne Memorial remembers the 502 sailors, marines and crew who lost their lives when both ships were torpedoed by German destroyers and sunk in the English Channel near Guernsey on 23rd October 1943 during Operation Tunnel. 
Operation Tunnel was mounted when the Royal Navy gained intelligence the Germans would be moving a convoy along the Brittany coast on the night of the 22nd/23rd October 1943. The cruiser HMS Charybdis accompanied six destroyers should have been a formidable force for the engagement, but it is thought that the German shore-based radar gave the enemy advance warning of the movements of the British ships. Although the Charybdis picked up the approach of enemy ships on her radar, it was too late to anticipate a joint torpedo attack by a group of German destroyers. 
The Charybdis was hit by a torpedo first, and the destroyer HMS Limbourne soon afterwards, both ships sank, and the German ships withdrew, undetected.

HMS Dunedin
HMS Dunedin, a Danae-class light cruiser, was launched in 1918. During the 1920s and 1930s she served as part of the New Zealand Division of the Royal Navy, sailing around the Pacific. Returning to England in 1937, she served at Portsmouth as a Boys Sea Training Ship until August 1939 when she was allocated to the 12th Cruiser Squadron based on Kirkwall for service on the Northern Patrol. 
Dunedin spent time hunting for German battleships and during 1940 was operating in the Caribbean Sea intercepting German merchant ships. On 15 June 1941, the German tanker Lothringen was captured by HMS Dunedin, denying German U-Boats of vital oil supplies. Important, classified Engima material was also discovered aboard the tanker during its capture. 
On 24 November 1941, whilst steaming in the Central Atlantic Ocean, east of the St. Paul's Rocks, HMS Dunedin was torpedoed and sunk by the German submarine U-124. Of her 486 crew, only four officers and 63 men survived. 
The memorial to HMS Dunedin was unveiled on 26th July 2003 by the last four known survivors.

HMS Formidable 
HMS Formidable was an Illustrious-class aircraft carrier (28,661 tons full load) that saw extensive service during the Second World War. She was commissioned on 24 November 1940.
HMS Formidable took part in the Battle of Cape Matapan on 27 March 1941. On 26 May 1941, she received serious damage while transporting aircraft to Malta, being hit by two 1000-kilogram bombs that put her out of action for six months. After repairs in the United States, she re-equipped with Vought Corsair and Martlet fighters.
In 1942, she travelled across the Pacific and served briefly in the Indian Ocean, returning to the Mediterranean in October. HMS Formidable then provided air support for the North African campaign and Italian campaign (1943), including the Allied invasion of Sicily, before taking part in an Arctic convoy. On 17 November aircraft from HMS Formidable attacked U-Boat U-331 (the U-Boat that sank HMS Barham) and sank her.
On 17 July 1944, Swordfish aircraft from HMS Formidable were involved in an attack on the Tirpitz in Norway and took part in further attacks on Tirpitz in August.
During 1945 she saw service against Japanese forces with British Pacific Fleet and survived several kamikaze attacks while supporting the landings on Okinawa. On 4 May a Japanese kamikaze plane crashed into the flight deck, making a massive dent about 10 feet long, two feet wide and two feet deep in the armoured flight deck. A large steel splinter ruptured a steam line, and came to rest in a fuel tank, starting a major fire in the aircraft park. Eight crew members were killed and forty-seven were wounded: the 3" armoured steel flight deck of HMS Formidable prevented further damage by Kamikaze attacks. By 5pm the fires were brought under control, the crater in the deck was repaired and Corsairs were again able to land on Formidable. A further Kamikaze hit HMS Formidable's flight deck on 9 May, but the level of damage was nowhere near as serious.
The accumulation of damage through the war took its toll on the ship. The bomb damage received in the Mediterranean had left her with damage that was beyond economical repair. She was placed in reserve in 1947 and was sold for scrap in 1953.
The blue plaque on the face of the stone memorial contains details of HMS Formidable’s Battle Honours and a reference to Lieutenant Robert Hampton Gray VC, DSC, RCNVR of 1841 Squadron - a Canadian naval officer, pilot, and posthumous recipient of the last Victoria Cross (VC) of the Second World War. Robert Hampton Gray is thought to be one of the last Canadians to die during the Second World War.
Located behind the main memorial to HMS Formidable is an oak tree which was planted by the HMS Formidable Association on 22 September 2001 and commemorates in tribute “all who served in and flew from this great ship”.

HMS Gambia 
HMS Gambia was a Crown Colony-class light cruiser of the Royal Navy and has been the only ship of the Royal Navy to bear the name. 
She saw active service in the East Indies with the British Eastern Fleet, and in September 1942, was involved in the Battle of Madagascar. Following a refit, she participated in Operation Stonewall to intercept blockade runners off the west coast of France. 
From 1943 - 1946 she was in the service of the Royal New Zealand Navy (RNZN) as HMNZS Gambia. She later served with the Far East Fleet and in 1950 was assigned to the 2nd Cruiser Squadron in the Mediterranean. 
In 1955, she became flagship of the 4th Cruiser Squadron on the East Indies Station and from 1960 remained in reserve at Portsmouth. 
The memorial is dedicated to the memory of the men of the Royal New Zealand Navy and the Royal Navy who served in HMS Gambia during her eight commissions 1942 – 1960. It was donated by the HMS Gambia Association 7th May 2005.

HMS GANGES 
HMS Ganges was established in 1905 as a Boy Seamans’ training school. It accepted boys between the ages of 15 and 16 ½ with the purpose of training them to be sailors fit to serve in His/Her Majesty's fleet. It was eventually closed in 1976 when initial training of all Naval Ratings transferred to HMS Raleigh in Cornwall. 
The HMS Ganges Association Memorial is located near to the Merchant Navy Convoy Wood. It comprises four cornerstones which represent the four countries of the United Kingdom from where the boys came. The stones are Cromar Lightning from Scotland, Plum Slate from Wales, Irish Quartzite from Ireland and Green Lakeland Slate from England. Each of the stones displays a carved national floral emblem: Scotland - Thistle, Wales - Daffodil, Ireland - Shamrock and England - Rose. 
The main central plinth is a piece of White Portland Stone onto which is carved the H.M.S. Ganges crest above the following dedication: 
This memorial is dedicated to the memory of all who passed through H.M.S Ganges at Shotley in Suffolk between the years 1905 and 1976." 
The memorial sits on a bed of green/blue shale, to represent the sea, which is enclosed within a course of Staffordshire Blue Bricks. 
Ganges was a Royal Navy Training Establishment at Shotley Gate near Ipswich for boys aged 15 and 16. It provided a tough regime involving education, (maths, English, navigation and naval history), physical education and parade ground drill. 
Between its establishment in 1905 and closure in 1976 around 160,000 recruits passed through its gates and it was often referred to as "the establishment that fed the fleet".

HMS Glory 
The memorial is dedicated to all who served on the Light Fleet Carrier HMS Glory between 1944 - 1957 and to those who lost their lives during that service. It was unveiled on 6 October 2007.

HMS Hood Memorial 
HMS Hood, named after the 18th Century Admiral Samuel Hood, was commissioned in 1920 and was the last battlecruiser built for the Royal Navy. For many years she was considered the largest and most powerful warship in the world - her prestige being reflected in the nickname "The Mighty Hood". 
HMS Hood was sunk in action with the German Battleship Bismarck in the Denmark Strait off Greenland on 24 May 1941. 
The memorial, which was dedicated on 25 October 2008, is of grey polish granite and displays HMS Hood’s crest, a Cornish Chough holding a gold anchor, which is based on elements of Lord Samuel Hood’s coat of arms. It is dedicated to the memory of the 1415 officers and ratings who died including 24 Commonwealth, 4 Polish Midshipmen and 5 Free French Sailors. Only 3 of the ship’s company survived. 
In 2015, the ship’s bell was recovered from the wreck of HMS Hood and conserved. It had been the expressed wish of Ted Briggs, one of the only three survivors, for this to be recovered as a memorial to his shipmates

HMS Kenya Memorial
HMS Kenya was a Crown Colony-class cruiser of the Royal Navy. Commissioned in 1940, she saw action during the Second World War hunting for the German battleship Bismarck in May 1941 and as part of Operation Stonewall, to intercept U-boats. She later took part in naval operations during the Korean War. 
The memorial, by the HMS Kenya Association, is dedicated to the comradeship and memory of the officers and men who served aboard HMS Kenya in times of war and peace from 1940-1962. 
The memorial is a light grey granite plinth displaying the name and an outline drawing of HMS Kenya on the front. On top of the plinth a polished black granite tablet is inscribed with a dedication and a list of battle honours reflecting her years of active service..

HMS Neptune and HMS Kandahar 
In December 1941, the destroyer HMS Kandahar and the cruiser HMS Neptune were sunk by mines in the Mediterranean with a loss of over 800 lives. 
The tragedy ranks among the heaviest crew losses experienced in any naval theatre of the Second World War and was the second most substantial loss of life suffered by the Royal Navy in the whole of the Mediterranean campaign. 
At 0300 on the 19th December the cruisers HMS Neptune (Captain Rory Chambers O’Connor), HMS Aurora (Captain William G Agnew CB) and HMS Penelope (Captain Angus Nichol DSO) and the destroyers Kandahar (Commander William Geoffrey Arthur Robson DSO, DSC), Lance (Lt-Commander R W F Northcott), Havok (Lt-Commander G R G Watkins DSC) and Lively (Lt-Commander W F E Hussey DSC) , the combined Forces B and K, steamed into a newly laid Italian minefield and HMS Neptune hit two mines and then while attempting to go astern hit a third. HMS Aurora and HMS Penelope also struck mines. HMS Kandahar attempted to pass a tow to the Neptune and struck a mine and had her stern blown off. Captain O’Conner warned all ships to stand clear. HMS Neptune sank later with the loss of all but one of her 765 crew; 150 were from New Zealand. 
On 20th December HMS Jaguar (Lt-Commander Lionel Rupert Tyrwhitt DSC) saved all but 91 of the crew of HMS Kandahar and then torpedoed the hulk. On 24th December, Able Seaman John Norman Walton, the only survivor from HMS Neptune was picked up by an Italian ship after spending 5 ½ days on a Carley raft. 
The pyramid shaped memorial is positioned so that it aligns with the position off the coast of Libya where the wreck of HMS Neptune lies. 
Concealed within the stone is a roll of honour of the 837 men who died and a painting of the sky as it was on the night of the sinking.

HMS PRINCE OF WALES AND REPULSE 
The Destruction of Force Z – The Sinking of HMS Prince of Wales and HMS Repulse in the South China Sea by the Japanese 22nd Air Flotilla. 
HMS Prince of Wales was a George V Class Battleship built by Cammell Laird, Birkenhead and commissioned in March 1941. She displaced 35,000 tons and had a main armament of 10 14 inch guns. 
She participated in the pursuit of the German Battleship Bismark and was struck 7 times during the battle resulting in the loss of 14 men. In August 1941, HMS Prince of Wales transported Sir Winston Churchill to meet Franklin D Roosevelt at Placenta Bay, Newfoundland where they created the Atlantic Charter.

She was commissioned in August 1916. She took part in the Battle of Heligoland Bight, was involved in refugee work at the outbreak of the Spanish War and in 1940 operated out of Norway and was on convoy duties until July 1941.

HMS Royal Arthur 
This polished grey stone obelisk shaped memorial is dedicated to all the men and women who entered service in the Royal Navy at HMS Royal Arthur at the former “Butlins Holiday Camp” Skegness between 1939 - 1945 and to all the officers and ratings who passed through HMS Royal Arthur, Corsham, Wiltshire in the years 1945 – 1993.
A gold naval anchor is inscribed in the memorial’s pyramidal top below which is the badge of HMS Royal Arthur displayed in blue and gold.
The inscription below includes a dedication remembering all HMS Royal Arthur shipmates who have ‘crossed the bar’ (a naval term used when comrades have passed away which is taken from Tennyson’s

HMS SHEFFIELD 
HMS Sheffield was a Type 42 guided missile destroyer and the second Royal Navy ship to be named after the city of Sheffield in Yorkshire. Commissioned on 16 February 1975 the Sheffield was part of the Task Force 317 sent to the Falkland Islands. 
On May 4 1982, the 4,100-ton destroyer was struck by a missile fired from an Argentine fighter bomber as it carried out a scouting mission off the Falklands - which Argentina had invaded and claimed as their own weeks earlier. 
The ship caught fire when a French-made Exocet missile hit HMS Sheffield and went deep into its control room. 
The blaze caused a poisonous smoke to be released and most of the crew abandoned ship. 
The “Shiny Sheff” 
The Shiny Sheff memorial honours the service of all those who served in the three ships of that name over 65 years and the 20 members of the Ship’s Company killed in action during the Falklands Conflict in 1982: 
The Cruiser (C24) 1937-67. World War 11 service 
The Destroyer (D80) 1970-82. Gulf and Falklands conflict 
The Frigate (F96) 1986-2002. Gulf. Awarded the Wilkinson Sword of Peace 
In 2020 with the 40th anniversary of the Falklands Conflict rapidly approaching the HMS SHEFFIELD Association agreed that a memorial should be placed at the National Memorial Arboretum to honour all those who served in the three ships of that name and that there should also be a place of remembrance for the 20 men lost when the second vessel of the name was damaged in action on the 4th of May 1982. In the spring of 2021, the artist Peter Naylor was commissioned to design a memorial which reflected all three ships and their close association with the city of Sheffield and its industries. The City of Sheffield Master Cutler was approached for assistance in making the memorial. The fabrication of the memorial was led by William Cook steel casting and supported by Tinsley Bridge, Outokumpu, and Charles Day Steels. The Association are extremely proud that their memorial was made of stainless steel by skilled craftsmen in the city of Sheffield. The memorial consists of a stainless-steel bow of a warship set in a stainless steel base, within in the deconstructed cruiser’s crest. The circular crest on the top of the memorial represents both destroyer and frigate. 
Materials Used 
Sheffield Stainless steel cast and sheet 
The memorial was constructed in January to April 2022 with ground-breaking in April 2022, it was unveiled by Mrs Penny Salt, widow of Captain Sam Salt, the Commanding Officer of the Destroyer HMS SHEFFIELD during the Falklands conflict. Mrs Salt consecrated the memorial on the 4th of May 2022 with a bottle of sea water collected in the South Atlantic by HMS Forth. 
Symbolism 
Positioned close to the South Atlantic Memorial and the corner of the Naval Field the memorial links the South Atlantic conflict with the large part played in that conflict by the Royal Navy and supporting Maritime services. 
The design of the memorial and its manufacture in stainless steel proudly links all three ships with the City of Sheffield and its world-famous steel industries. When they were constructed all three warships were presented with ship’s bells and fittings of stainless steel made in Sheffield. 
The memorial represents a warship at speed as it cuts through a dull grey sea during operations. The sea is set in the deconstructed pentagonal crest of the cruiser which links the second world war generation of sailors to the modern era. 
The warship crest on the top of the memorial takes the sheaf of arrows from the city of Sheffield Coat of Arms. The sheaf of arrows is a wordplay on the river Sheaf which runs through Sheffield and is also a reference to the iron and steel making heritage of the city.

THE HMT LANCASTRIA 
HMT Lancastria a troopship, which was sunk off the coast of France, near St Nazaire, in June 1940. Lancastria was carrying both service personnel and civilians; it is unknown how many were on board at the time but some estimates are up 9,000. This was such a catastrophe that that Churchill ordered a “D Notice” - a total news blackout - for fear of the damage this may do to the country's morale. 
In WW2 many ocean-going pleasure liners were requisitioned by the British Government to support the war effort. 
HMT Lancastria's capacity was 1,300 passengers, it was deployed to St Nazaire, France, to assist in the evacuation of British Nationals and troops from France, two weeks after Dunkirk. 
On the 17 June 1940 it was agreed to load 3,000 onto the ship but that number increased during the boarding, estimated between 5,000 and 9,000. 
The Captain of Lancastria could have left port around 14:00 but the RN destroyer which was to escort it had been bombed by the Germans. 
So Lancastria's Captain decided to wait for an escort. Index 
Unfortunately, while waiting, a fresh air raid began at around 16:00 and Lancastria was hit by three or possibly four bombs. 
A number of survivors reported that one of the bombs had gone down the ships only funnel causing the ship to sink quickly - around 15-20 minutes. 
Opinions differ on actual loss of life but the general consensus is at least 3,000, up to around 7,000. 
A simple stone memorial is located in front of the ‘Lancastria Oak’ within the Merchant Navy Woodland, bearing a circular plaque inscribed with the Lancastria Association badge and emblem. 
The story of the Lancastria is little known but represents the biggest disaster in British maritime history. 
On 17 June 1940, the 16,000-ton Cunard liner Lancastria lay five miles off St Nazaire embarking troops, RAF personnel and civilian refugees, including women and children, who were being evacuated from France, which was then on the point of collapse. The exact number of people on board may never be known, but almost certainly exceeded 6,000; some estimates were as high as 9,000. 
The Lancastria was attacked and hit by bombs from German aircraft. The ship sank rapidly and, according to the estimate of the Commanding Officer, Captain Rudolf Sharpe, only around 2,500 of those on board were saved. 
Due to the scale of the tragedy and in the interests of public morale (this also being the day that the French government decided to seek an armistice with Nazi Germany), Winston Churchill forbade publication of the news at the time, hence the story of the Lancastria has never been generally known, although it is Britain’s worst maritime disaster. 
Since the Second World War, the Lancastria Association and Lancastria Association of Scotland have established memorials to the victims and carry out remembrance services every year.

HOME FRONT MEMORIAL Map The term "home front" covers the activities of the civilians in a nation at war. World War II was a total war; homeland production and sustainability became even more invaluable. Life on the home front during World War II was a significant part of the war effort for all participants and had a major impact on the outcome of the war. Governments became involved with new issues such as rationing, manpower allocation, home defence, evacuation in the face of air raids, and response to occupation by an enemy power.

Kenya Police Memorial
