The memorial consists of a 6 feet tall obelisk of black Indian marble whichhighlights significant events in the history of the force. The photographs etched on the memorial depict various aspects of their work including air patrols as shown by the aircraft flying past Mount Kenya.

Leyton Orient Somme
The O’s Somme Memorial honours the service and sacrifice of the 41 players, staŽ, club o›cials and supporters of Clapton Orient Football Club (now Leyton Orient FC) in the First World War. It is the first Memorial to commemorate a football club at the National Memorial Arboretum, which is very apt as Clapton Orient were the first English Football League club to enlist en masse into the British Army. Lions International (Shelter No 4)
The Lions is a charitable organisation dedicated to serving local, national and international communities. The memorial is a shelter dedicated to the memory of Lions from Great Britain and Ireland in grateful thanks for their service.
Opened on 14 September 2011, by HRH The Countess of Wessex, Royal Patron of the Lions Clubs of the British Isles and a member of Wokingham Lions Club, this shelter provides a place to reflect on how much ordinary people can do when they work together.
There are millions of volunteer Lions Clubs members around the world who are working hard to improve their local communities. They do this by raising money for good causes, as well as supporting international campaigns, helping those less fortunate and having fun by organising all kinds of activities.
Before their 2017 centenary, Lions Clubs everywhere adopted the message: “Where there’s a need, there’s a Lion” and took on a challenge to serve 100 million people.

LISBON MARU
The Lisbon Maru Memorial was erected in memory of the 828 victims who died in one of the worst war crimes perpetrated by the Japanese during World War Two. British prisoners of war captured at the fall of Hong Kong were being transported to Japan to work as slaves. After their ship was torpedoed the Japanese rescued their own troops but locked the POWs in the holds leaving them to drown, and shot at those who managed to break out. In 1942 the Japanese began sending POWs from their captured territories to Japan to work as slave labour in various industries so as to free up the workforce to be enlisted into the armed forces. The second shipment of POWs from Hong Kong was on the Lisbon Maru. On 27 September 1942 the Lisbon Maru, a Japanese armed freighter with Japanese troops on board, sailed from Hong Kong bound for Japan. It also carried 1,816 British prisoners of war held in atrocious conditions. Cramped, airless, and in unimaginable squalor they were incarcerated below deck in three cargo holds. The freighter bore no markings to indicate their presence. On 1 October an American submarine, the USS Grouper, on patrol off the Zhoushan archipelago in the East China Sea, engaged the Lisbon Maru holing it below the waterline with a torpedo. Although initially taken under tow, the line snapped and the ship drifted and foundered. The Japanese evacuated their troops, battened down the hatches over the holds and left a guard force to prevent the prisoners from escaping. For 24 hours the prisoners were held in sub-human conditions in darkness with no food, water, fresh air or sanitation; and dysentery was rife. There was a breakout before the ship sank the next day and many of the prisoners of war escaped from the two forward holds, some of whom were cut down by machine-gun fire. Most of those in the third hold, by then below the waterline, tragically drowned. Those who did escape were shot at in the water as they attempted to swim to the shore; many were killed or wounded but local Chinese fishermen courageously rescued 384 of the survivors. Later, the Japanese recaptured all but three.
Of the original 1,816 men on board 828 died in this terrible atrocity and a further 200 or more succumbed from their sufferings within a few months.

LOCH CLASS FRIGATES CAIRN  
The memorial is dedicated to the men of the Ship’s Companies who served the Loch Class Frigates and their variants in the North Atlantic, Artic, India (Burma) and Pacific Oceans during the Second World War and in all spheres until 1970. 
The circular stone memorial, resembling a cairn, is finished with stones from each of the 28 named Scottish Lochs.

A frigate is a small warship; in WW2 mainly used against submarines. A Corvette is rather smaller and was used mainly to protect merchant ship convoys.

The L.S.T. and Landing Craft Association Memorial 
Landing Ship, Tank (LST), or tank landing ships were built during the Second World War to support amphibious operations by carrying tanks, vehicles and cargo and landing troops directly on to shore. As their unique design meant that they could provide amphibious assaults to any beach they were used extensively around the world in both the European and Pacific theatres. 
The L.S.T. and Landing Craft Association Memorial is dedicated to all those who served in or in support of Landing Ships and Landing Craft especially those who gave their lives in service of their country.

MALAYA AND BORNEO VETERANS’ MEMORIAL
This memorial is dedicated to the many thousands of men who fought in Malaysia, Borneo, Singapore and Brunei. The large granite stone is expected to last 2000 years, providing a lasting memorial to the estimated 30,000 men who fought in the Second World War, the Malayan Emergency, the Confrontation and further conflicts in southeast Asia. It is intended as a place of quiet reflection for thousands of men and their families, remembering those who made the ultimate sacrifice and those who have departed subsequent to the end of hostilities.

ALAY VOLUNTEER FORCE MEMORIAL
The Malayan Volunteers Group, mostly children of volunteers with some veterans, was formed in 2005 to commemorate and raise awareness of the Malayan volunteers in the Malayan Campaign and captivity 1941 – 1945. Some 18,000 volunteers of different races and creeds served in the Malayan Volunteer Forces, Medical Auxiliary Service and Observer Corps, receiving 100 Campaign Awards. In captivity, they contributed practical and medical skills, knowledge of local languages and secret radios, saving lives and giving hope of victory. Others taught in ‘Changi University’.

MERCHANT NAVY ASSOCIATION
Although there had been merchant vessels throughout history, at the end of WW1, in recognition of their service, King George V bestowed the title Merchant Navy on them. 
The title "Master of the Merchant Navy and Fishing Fleets" is held by the reigning Monarch. 
The Merchant Navy Association (MNA) was formed in 1989. Its purpose is to ensure the welfare of both serving and former Merchant Navy personnel.

The Merchant Navy Convoy Wood 
The Merchant Navy Convoy Wood is dedicated to over 46,000 British merchant seafarers and fishermen lost in conflict during the 20th century, including two World Wars, Falklands, Kuwait, Vietnam, Iran, Iraq and others. 
During the Second World War, 31,908 seafarers perished, proportionately more than any of the Armed Services. 
Originally the wood had 2,535 trees, each representing a British vessel lost at that time; the number of trees has been significantly reduced by the need to thin out the wood as the trees matured. Oak was the material originally used for building ships. Additionally, the wood was planted with bluebells to represent the sea. 
The ships cargoes included food, troops, armaments, ammunition and fuel carried to the United Kingdom and every theatre of war. The seafarers were civilians who faced the enemy and the sea with equal bravery and courage, to keep the supply lines open to Britain and its allies.

Mesothelioma UK - Supporting our Armed Forces
In memory of members of the UK armed forces who have been diagnosed with the asbestos-related cancer, mesothelioma. Mesothelioma is a cancer caused by asbestos that affects around 2,700 people in the UK each year. A number of those diagnosed are, or were, serving members of the Armed Forces. As part of a Government-funded project, national charity, Mesothelioma UK supported research into the effects of mesothelioma within our armed forces. Findings from the research informed the development of the charity’s UK-wide specialist service for armed forces personnel and veterans who have been affected by mesothelioma. As part of the project, the charity wanted to create a memorial to honour those who have lost their lives to the disease or are living with it. The memorial depicts building blocks of life, engraved with information about mesothelioma, asbestos and our Armed Forces. 
Materials Used
Ancaster Weatherbed limestone
Name of Designers
Graeme Mitcheson M.M.R.S.
Age of Memorial
The construction began in spring 2023. A dedication ceremony is due to be held in October 2023.
Symbolism and meaning
The building blocks of life are represented by solid blocks of carved stone, constructed in a format not dissimilar to the game Jenga. The sculpture shows that even though the tower of blocks has been damaged in the middle, it is strongly supported above and below. This represents the aims of the charity. In addition to the tall tower of blocks. Each face will have carved across the surface of the stone, an inscription that describes both the aims of Mesothelioma UK and details of the disease. Some of the sections are slightly jumbled as the blocks have collapsed. The inscriptions are designed in such a way that the viewer is compelled to study the jumbled words and to try to rearrange the sentences in their heads, all the time learning a little about the charity and about mesothelioma. The Memorial has been created to allow families and friends of those affected to be able to visit the memorial and pay their respects or celebrate a key milestone.

MILITARY MEDALLISTS’ MEMORIAL
The Military Medal was first established by King George V on 25 March 1916 to award Warrant Officers and other ranks for bravery in battle on land. It was awarded to members of the British Army and related services such as QAIMNS when the medal could be awarded to women after a ruling in 1916. The Military Medal was awarded for acts of bravery that were not deemed high enough for the DSM. In WW1 over 115,000 MMs were awarded with around 6000 bars. WW2 saw some 15,000 MMs along with 177 bars. The medal ceased to be awarded in 1993 and was replaced by the Military Cross. The final MMs were awarded for service in the last round of troubles in Northern Ireland between 1969-1993. (1969-2007) The memorial recognises all who were awarded the Military Medal since its inception in 1916.

Naval Service Memorial 
The Naval Service Memorial is located at the heart of the Naval Section of the Arboretum and commemorates those who have served, serve today and will serve tomorrow, regardless of rank, trade or fighting arm. 
The striking memorial was created by Graeme Mitcheson, from a theme developed by Lt Cdr Nigel Huxtable. It is comprised of 13 coloured glass panels on a white granite terrace and includes a figure of Kilkenny limestone. 
The glass depicts the colours of the five oceans – steel grey with spume lines for the Atlantic, turquoise for the Indian, ultramarine for the Pacific and white for the Arctic and Southern oceans. 
Yellow is for the rising sun, red for the setting sun and the blood spilled at sea, and on land. 
On the memorial’s terrace stands a figure of a sailor, head bowed in respect to shipmates everywhere, cap held in the ‘at ease’ position. The figure faces west, where the sun sets. The terrace has a carved inscription of the Tennyson poem ‘Crossing the Bar’ – a phrase used when shipmates pass away. 
The glass panels cast a shadow suggesting the shape of a warship. Visible only in sunlight and for a few hours per day, it is best seen on 11 November. 
The curved shapes suggest waves and motion while the scale and colour hint at sails in a harbour. The idea for the ‘warship shadow’ came when the designer was in his garden, on a summer’s day, watching shadows cast by washing hanging on the line. 
The Naval Service Memorial was unveiled on 15 June 2014 by HRH Prince Michael of Kent. 
The coloured glass memorial was commissioned by the Royal Naval Association to mark the 60th anniversary of its being granted a Royal Charter. 
The 13 glass panels depict the different colours of the oceans of the world, while yellow is for the rising sun and red the setting sun. There are also splashes of red representing the blood spilled at sea, on land and in the air in defence of our nation. 
The panels cast a shadow, suggesting the shape of a warship, which is best seen around lunchtime when the sun is directly behind. 
The single figure faces the setting sun, head bowed, and cap held in the 'at ease' position, showing respect to his fallen shipmates. 
On the terrace edge is a carved inscription from the Tennyson poem 'Crossing the Bar', which is the phrase used by Navy personnel when a shipmate has passed away.

Number 2 Squadron is the most senior squadron of the RAF, formed on 13th may 1912 0n the founding day of the RFC as one of the first three squadrons formed. 
Numbers 2 and 3 were equipped with fixed wing aircraft while number one with airships.

No. 47 Squadron RAF Memorial
No. 47 Squadron Royal Flying Corps was formed on 1 March 1916 at Beverley as a home defence unit to protect Hull and East Yorkshire against attacks from German Zeppelins. The Squadron saw active service in East Africa, the Eastern Mediterranean and India during the Second World War and later supported the Berlin Airlift. In more recent times the Squadron supported United Nations (UN) and NATO operations in the Balkans by delivering aid to besieged cities and also assisted coalition forces in operations in Iraq and Afghanistan. Also in this area… Take a look inside our original Type 24 Pillbox, where soldiers during the Second World War were expected to use the reinforced concrete walls for protection, whilst fighting an invading enemy. There is an information panel just outside if you’d like to find out more. The memorial’s five figures represent two airmen from the First World War and Second World War and the other three figures represent a modern air crew. An introductory plinth displays the Squadron badge depicting a demoiselle crane’s head in front of a fountain. The memorial also includes nine corten steel plaques that represent the Squadron’s battle honours.

49 Squadron RAF 
The memorial to 49 Squadron is made of polished South African Dark Grey granite. The circular headpiece, fixed to a rectangular base, depicts the squadron’s badge - a racing greyhound surmounting the motto 'Cave Canem' (Beware of the Dog) and is surrounded by the inscription: 49 Bomber Squadron Royal Air Force. The badge was officially recognised on 14 June 1937 following the Squadron’s relocation to Worthy Down.
The base of the memorial is inscribed with the words:
In memory of those who served on 49 Squadron 1916 – 1965
49 Squadron was originally formed during the First World War at Dover in April 1916. Its first 18 months were spent as an aircrew training unit equipped with BE2Cs, RE7s and Martinsydes. Between 1917 and 1918 the squadron was tasked with day bombing raids and high and low level bombing until the end of the war when it was subsequently disbanded in July 1919.
During the Second World War the reformed squadron operated as a front line bomber squadron and took part in most major operations by Bomber Command equipped with Lancaster Bombers. In peacetime the squadron carried out routine training and also saw action in Kenya.
In 1956, equipped with Valiant B1 aircraft (the first of the V Bombers), the squadron was tasked with carrying out a series of nuclear tests based on Christmas Island in the Pacific Ocean.
Reverting to the normal medium bomber role the squadron moved to Marham in 1961. On 5 June 1964 Her Royal Highness Princess Marina, Duchess of Kent, presented 49 Squadron with its standard.
49 Squadron was disbanded at RAF Marham on 1 May 1965, when all Valiant aircraft were withdrawn from service.
Honours and awards gained by members of 49 Squadron during the Second World War include:
1 Victoria Cross (VC)
(Awarded to Flight Lieutenant (later Wing Commander) Roderick Alastair Brook Learoyd for his bravery during the successful low level attack on the Dortmund Ems canal, 12 August 1940. It was the first VC awarded in Bomber Command.
1 Empire Gallantry Medal (later the George Cross)
7 Distinguished Service Orders
131 Distinguished Flying Crosses
2 Conspicuous Gallantry Medals
105 Distinguished Flying Medals

RAF PATH FINDER FORCE MEMORIAL (NO. 8 GROUP) 
Path Finder Force formed August 1942, part of Bomber Command (they were used for target-marking to increase accuracy of bombing raids). Mainly RAF but also personnel from other Commonwealth countries. It was steadily transformed from a token ‘hit & miss’ Force to one that could deliver anything from a single Bomb to 100’s of tonnes of bombs accurately onto a target anywhere in Western Europe. ‘Cherry-picking’ crews from other areas of the RAF was frowned upon at the time but it would have been the Crème de la Crème of crews that had the skills and experience needed. The airmen committed to doing another 60 operations, later reduced to 45 (and the more you did, the less the chance of surviving). Crews for specific missions were hand-picked. Aircraft used included Halifax, Lancaster, Wellington and Mosquito and Stirling. Project to get a memorial started in 2014. It was originally unveiled at the PFF Reunion at RAF Wyton (August 2017), 75 years after No.8 Group was formed. Text:
Pegasus Bridge Memorial Flight
'Operation Deadstick'
On D-Day 6th June 1944 six Horsa Gliders were released by Halifax pilots of 298 and 644 Squadrons Royal Air Force. Gliding down over enemy territory in complete darkness the crews of the Glider Pilot Regiment crash landed 5 of the Gliders very close to the bridges over the Orne River and Caen Canal. Glider No. 4 landed by a bridge over the River Dives about 10 miles away. Capture of these bridges was vital to defending the D-Day landing beaches in Normandy to the North and the Airborne Forces drop zones to the East in the vicinity of Ranville. The operation was planned by Major John Howard and the successful assault by soldiers from the 2nd. Battalion Oxfordshire & Buckinghamshire Light Infantry who were supported by the Royal Engineers, Royal Army Medical Corps and a 7 Para liaison officer. The 5 metre high memorial depicts three stylised Horsa gliders spiralling down on a giant letter 'S' representing this Secret operation that was carried out in Silence, using Speed, Stealth and achieved complete Surprise. The concept of the memorial was by Mike Colton and the memorial brought to life by Bromley O'Hare, Blacksmith/Artisan with the sides left open to indicate that the Gliders were frail craft!
Memorial Established 2018.

POPPY MEMORIAL
The memorial, provided by The Royal British Legion (began in 1921), features a giant wreath around which poppies, inscribed with individual names and dates, can be planted as a permanent tribute. It’s a place where everyday heroes, as well as those killed in conflict, can be honoured. (Became ‘Royal’ in 1971). Popski’s Private Army
Popski’s Private Army was founded by Major Vladimir Peniakoff in Cairo in October 1942. On 10 December 1942, it became officially operational as “No. 1 Demolition Squadron, PPA” an 8th Army Special Forces unit formed specifically to attack Field-Marshal Rommel’s fuel supplies, in support of General Montgomery’s offensive at El Alamein. The squadron, which also served in Italy, was disbanded in September 1945 as well as the Long
Range Desert Group (LRDG) and the Special Air Service (SAS), PPA was the last and smallest of the three main irregular raiding, reconnaissance and intelligence units formed during the North African Campaign. The stone built memorial is a truncated pyramid topped with the PPA astrolabe unit symbol replicated from Popski’s original design which is also echoed in the shape of the surrounding low hedge. The variegated laurel hedge represents the yellow of the deserts of North Africa and the greenery of Italy. Commemorative plaques feature on all four faces of the memorial. The front displays a small plaque showing PPA's astrolabe cap badge, a small plaque commemorating the unveiling on 30 March 2008 (Popski's Birthday), together with the PPA Roll of Honour. To the rear PPA Honours and Awards are listed. The right-hand plaque commemorates the 27th Lancers and all the units who comprised "Porterforce" with the Italian Partisans commemorated on the left-hand plaque. In 2010, two plaques telling the story Popski's Private Army were added to the memorial’s entrance. The design of the hedge around the memorial was by Mike Colton. Dedicated in 2008.
