Memorial: Women's Royal Army Corps Memorial ; WRAC
Text:
WOMEN’s ROYAL ARMY CORPS 
Women served in both World Wars in various units and by the end of the Second World War it was acknowledged that women would be a valuable asset to a peace-time army, so the Women’s Royal Army Corps was formed.
They served all over the world in over 35 trades and over 1200 died in service.
The WRAC was disbanded in 1992
The raised beds form the letter ‘W’, while the trees and bushes either have ladies’ names or their foliage/flowers are the colours of the women’s uniforms.
Also in the garden is are two statues dedicated to all the women who served in the Auxiliary Territorial Service (ATS).
When the ATS was formed in 1938 there were 5 main trades: Cook, Clerk, Orderly, Store woman and Driver but as time passed, more and more trades were taken over, including highly-skilled and technical work and tasks which the organisation of the army depended upon, such as equipment and ammunition. Index
The Queen served in the ATS as 2nd Lieutenant Elizabeth Windsor as did Mary Churchill, the youngest daughter of Winston.
The ATS and WRAC memorials were both designed by Andy de Comyn
Andy de Comyn also designed the Shot at Dawn, Mercian Volunteers, Women’s RAF and National Miners memorials at the NMA
The ATS ACK- ACK memorial was relocated into this garden when the National Miners Memorial was erected at the NMA
During WW1 the code for the letter A in the phonetic alphabet was ‘Ack’, so the AA of Anti-Aircraft became ‘Ack-Ack’.
These girls had a strong link with the Royal Artillery, especially working alongside them in the anti-aircraft batteries. Officially the girls did everything apart from firing the guns (this was a political decision rather than a physical one), but we have had former ‘Ack-Ack’ ladies here who tell us they most certainly DID fire the guns, saying there is no way they would let their homes be bombed just because there wasn’t a man there to pull the lever.

WOMEN'S ROYAL NAVAL SERVTCE (WRNS)
The installation of the AOW Centenary Stone took place on Wednesday 23rd September 2020 in the WRNS Garden. The memorial represents one hundred years since the Association was formed and it is very fitting that installation was able to go ahead in what should have been a year of celebration when so many planned events had to be cancelled. The stone was constructed by Robyn Golden-Hann. It represents not only former wrens but also the Women of the Royal Naval Services as they are today. The WRNS were founded in l9l7 to support the men of the Royal Navy, but were disbanded in 1919. In 1939, at the outbreak of WW2, they were re-established and remained in service until 1993 when they were fully integrated into the Royal Navy. Women now carry out exactly the same duties as their male counterparts, both at sea and ashore. The garden is dedicated to all who served in the service and is designed to encourage birds, insects and butterflies. The pathways form the shape of an anchor. The wren, which was carved by the Essex Woodcarvers, forms part of a memorial for the 21 WRNS and a Naval Nursing Sister who lost their lives when their ship, SS Aguila, was torpedoed inl94l. One of the first WRNS to see active service was Wendy Clayin, who in 1990, served on board HMS Brilliant. The Women’s Royal Naval Service (WRNS), known as the Wrens, was formed in 1917 to release Royal Navy men for sea service during the First World War. It was disbanded after the war. On 11th April 1939 Vera Laughton Matthews was appointed Director of the newly reformed Women’s Royal Naval Service WRNS: she had previously been a member during World War 1. It was originally envisaged that there would be about 3000 women in the WRNS, however at its peak the number was more than 65,000. Around 75,000 Wrens carried out highly confidential and responsible roles in Britain and overseas. The WRNS was fully integrated into the Royal Navy in 1993.
Index
This charming garden at the far end of the Royal Naval Review is dedicated to the WRNS and has been designed to encourage birds, insects and butterflies. The paths are in the shape of an anchor. Buddleia shrubs provide a haven for butterflies in summer. The two rose beds are planted with “Wren” roses to celebrate the 90th anniversary of the Association of Wrens 1917 – 2007. Notcutts Nurseries developed this rose for the 2007 Chelsea Flower Show and donated plants to the Wrens Garden at the NMA. In the rose beds and against the trees may be found dedications to individual Wrens.
Located in the garden is the Aguila Memorial, a beautifully carved wren which commemorates the 21 WRNS and one Naval Nursing Sister who were lost when SS Aguila was torpedoed in 1941 (see M-152 Aguilla Memorial).

Memorial: Women's Section Memorial, The Royal British Legion
Text:
RBL Women’s Section 
The British Legion Women’s Section was formed in 1921 to safeguard the interests of widows and families of ex-Servicemen. It was also to provide a way for women to be a part of the British Legion and widen its activities. The Women’s Section is autonomous, self-funding, and also comes under the Royal Charter with Her Royal Highness the Princess Royal as the National President.

“Y” LISTENING GROUP 
The paths in this garden are laid out in the form of a letter ‘Y’. 
 “Y” comes from the initials for “Wireless Interception”…….”WI” sound like “Y” 
Inspiration for the memorial came from a group of ATS (Auxiliary Territorial Service) ladies who served in the War Office ‘Y’ Group at Beaumanor Hall, near Loughborough and other such stations. 
During WW2 men and women who were found to have the required skills and passed intensive Morse code training were recruited to serve at secret listening stations around the UK to monitor German radio transmissions which had been encoded using Enigma machines. 
Once intercepted the enemy's military messages, still in code, were sent to Bletchley Park - also known as Station X - to be decrypted by its talented, ingenious and often eccentric code-breakers. 
The Germans did not believe that radio messages sent over short distances in occupied Europe could be picked up in England. They could! In short, without the Y Service, Bletchley would not have had the coded Enigma messages to decipher, and the work of these combined teams of many thousands of secret and silent heroes is now widely acknowledged as having shortened WW2 by at least two years. 
Winston Churchill called those involved his "geese that laid the golden eggs but never cackled". 
In the right-hand corner is a bench in memory of the 3 Royal Navy men from the warship HMS Petard - Colin Grazier, Tony Fasson and Tommy Brown - who were instrumental in recovering code books from a sinking German submarine in 1942, which helped considerably in breaking the German Enigma code. 
Unfortunately, Colin Grazier (a native of Tamworth) and Tony Fasson drowned when the submarine sank. Both were awarded the George Cross.

Yangtze Incident Memorial 
The Yangtze Incident memorial commemorates those who lost their lives when the British Royal Navy ship HMS Amethyst was trapped on the Yangtze River for three months during the Chinese Civil War in 1949. 
The circular planting of 46 Chinese euonymus plants commemorates each life lost during the Yangtze Incident in China in 1949. 
A plaque alongside the memorial tells the full story of the Yangtze Incident. Inside the circle is a black polished granite monument and trees planted as a tribute to HMS Amethyst, HMS Black Swan, HMS Consort and HMS London which were the four ships involved in the incident. The human cost in the four ships was 46 dead and 68 injured. 
The tree planted just outside the circle remembers the RAF Sunderland flying boat, named D-DOG ML772, from 88 Squadron. On its fourth attempt it landed successfully on the Yangtze River alongside HMS Amethyst to deliver medical supplies and a replacement doctor. 
Royal Indian Navy and Army Memorial Map 
Between the Yangtze Incident and Far East Air Force memorials, trees from the Indian sub-continent such as Kashmir rowan, cedar and Bhutan pine have been planted as a tribute to those who served in the Royal Indian Navy (1934 – 1947) and Indian Army. The memorial lies within a small area surrounded by a hedge. 
The British Indian Army (1858 – 1947) was a force recruited locally during the British Colonisation of India and commanded by British and Indian officers. Substantial numbers of Indian soldiers served in both World Wars. Note also the memorials to the Dogra, Baluch and Sikh soldiers. 
The Royal Indian Navy had its origins in the East India Company’s Marine, later the Bombay Marine. From 1830 to 1858 the Bombay Marine became the Indian Navy. After the end of Company rule in 1857 the name reverted to Bombay Marine until in 1877 it was renamed Her Majesties Indian Marine. In 1892 it became the Royal Indian Marine. With the introduction of the Indian Navy (Discipline) Act 1934, the Royal Indian Navy was formally inaugurated on 2nd October 1934; its ships carried the prefix HMIS. During WW2 the service greatly expanded, and the Women’s Royal Indian Naval Service was established. Two of its sloops HMIS Sutlej and HMIS Jumna played a role in the invasion of Sicily. In 1947 the Navy was split between India and Pakistan. From 1950 when India became a republic the ships have been prefixed INS.

YMCA Memorial
The YMCA is an international Christian movement. The memorial is dedicated to all those who, through the YMCA, served the Armed Forces in times of war and peace, some of whom gave their lives in the service of others.
